messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Mike, This list is probably the right place to go if you want to find out if what you ve got is probably authentic, and get some idea as to date, style,
messages.messageBody:
Mike,

This list is probably the right place to go if you want to find out if
what you've got is "probably" authentic, and
get some idea as to date, style, etc., if legitimate, and is a great
place to start if you actually wish to
learn more about tsuba, fittings, etc.,.

That being said, the easiest first step would be to take some pictures
or scans of the tsuba, put them up on your website
(or just get a yahoo photos account - they're free, and you can store 30
meg of pictures there), and post pointers to the
pictures on this list - there are actually a number of knowledgable
individuals on this list, and you'll usually get at least
some comments about them...

Good Luck,

rkg
(Richard George)

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Hello, I am new on this site and am also the recipient of about a dozen tsuba. I was told that they are dated somewhere around the third century? My question
messages.messageBody:
Hello,
I am new on this site and am also the recipient of about a dozen tsuba. I was told that they are dated somewhere around the third century? My question is where do I go to get an honest apraised value on these items. I am not a collector of this type so have no earthly idea where to seek information. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks,
Mike

-----Original Message-----
From: yamaimojg [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Thursday, February 12, 2004 10:32 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: shinsa question


Rick,
Just saw your question. As described it sounds like it's a koshirae
that should pass shinsa. The point to submitting it would be do get
written certification of its age, completeness, quality, etc.
Whether that is worth doing is up to you. There should be an NTHK
shinsa coming to a coast near you in the next couple or few years.

Jim

messages.subject: Re: shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, guys n gals, thought I d drop in momentarily.  Re the thread on papering koshirae, can I solicit some advice on one of my few attic finds ?  The blade
messages.messageBody:
Hi, guys 'n' gals, thought I'd drop in momentarily. Re the thread on
papering koshirae, can I solicit some advice on one of my few "attic
finds"? The blade has already been papered (sent back to Japan,
papered hozon, nice old polish Eisho era unokubi zukuri, but tired).
The koshirae (not sent) has been assessed by One Who Should Know as
original and correct pre-Meiji, absolutely NSW (Not Screwed With).
Mostly in excellent condition, no wear or soil to the tsuka ito,
even. I would guess that papering the koshirae would be a slam dunk,
except

1. The saya is dinged up. Not terribly badly, but far from
pristine. It would be a bastard to repair, because in strong light,
the "black" lacquer is seen to be black with translucent brown
streaks running through it.

2. The kashira is for correct court wear, i.e., it is black horn, not
a kinko match for the fuchi (which is signed, though the apparently
matching tsuba isn't).

3. Though the tsuba has the hitsu, there are no accessories, and no
provisions for any in the saya.

Sooooooo, would there be any real point to submitting this to
shinsa? It is pre-Meiji original, but no "knock your socks off".
Just wondering, in case a shinsa shows up again on the US west coast
in my lifetime!

NC ;o)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Easy question first -- the usual translation of tekkotsu is iron bones.  Don t think of a dry skeleton here, it s more like the look of your knuckle
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
Easy question first -- the usual translation of tekkotsu is "iron bones." Don't think of a dry skeleton here, it's more like the look of your knuckle bones and skin when you make a fist.

I'm no longer so sure about the idea of tsuba surfaces being remelted. It's mentioned in various sources and seems like a plausible process. It looks a lot like the melted glaze on a piece of ceramic. But when I talk about this with smiths they do not believe that it is possible. They say that the surface would be burned rather than melted. I have followed up with questions about fluxes and atmospheres that might make it possible, but haven't gotten anywhere. However, I also haven't gotten anywhere when I ask how they think that those "melted" surfaces were really produced. I'm still looking for answers on this one.

There are other groups that made these "melted" yakite finishes.

Also, there are a number of other explanations for the formation of tekkotsu including inhomogeneities in carbon content and subsequent wear and rusting. I think that there is some truth in all of them. I had a chance to glance at the link that Rich provided and I think that it is good stuff. Busy day today, so a quick answer.

Jim


Hi Jim, on the website you write: ' These tsuba appear to have been
finished by slightly melting the surface after forging and shaping. This
brings out tekkotsu from the high carbon inclusions in the iron'

Was this done at any other schools or is this peculiar to Kanayama?

Als if you had to translate 'tekkotsu' in English what would it be? I
know what it is (at least I think I do) but I can't for the life of me
think what you would call it in English.

Matt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, I have thought about this alot and only recently have come to a conclusion.  Given my desire for only mantis themed items, I couldn t decide to mount them
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

I have thought about this alot and only recently have
come to a conclusion. Given my desire for only mantis
themed items, I couldn't decide to mount them or not
(one day when I do remount a sword or 2). I came to
the conclusion that I enjoy seeing all these items
grouped together in my display table and having them
all together makes them available for quick study. I
therefore decided not to mount them (my mantis items).
On the other hand I decided when I do remount some
swords, that I may choose a secondary theme like
fishing (other passion of mine) to mount in. I may
also just opt for just a shirasaya but have recently
been leaning toward a bit nicer of a display (matching
fittings, handle wrap, etc). When I view my items it
is usually just the swords or just fittings, depends
on my mood. I also know that I am unique in that I
collect 1 theme, although there are many others like
me out there. However, if I were to find a sword with
all mantis fittings, I would keep it together. 1
tsuba on a sword would most likely be stripped and
replaced with something else, especially if I didn't
have that tsuba school represented. I wonder if guys
into iado/ sword practitioners or musuem guys (Gordon)
view the whole package ,sword, fittings, saya, etc as
one, while I tend to view it in terms of seperate
entities. I'm rambling here so I'll stop. It all
comes down to Personal preference- no right or wrong.

Ken

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Although I am sure to take some heat for this, my feelings have always been that mounts belong on swords and not in boxes. However, there are mounts and then
messages.messageBody:
Although I am sure to take some heat for this, my feelings have always been
that mounts belong on swords and not in boxes. However, there are mounts and
then there are swords and they should be at the same level if put together.
Still, your approach is often taken everywhere, including Japan.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Wednesday, January 21, 2004 2:55 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question



Gordon -

A personal dilemma. Last March I've purchased a beautiful mumei katana with
fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae which had damage. I've
had the sword put into shirazaya and a tsunagi made for the koshirae with
repairs, on-going. Because the tsuka wrapping was literally falling apart,
the fuchi/kashira and menuki were removed and therefore, able to be examined
in-hand. The menuki are solid gold "dragons" which are super! The
fuchi/kashira (mumei) are even more fine and really do cry for shinsa with
an eye toward Goto. The kozuka/kogai looked "mainline Goto" but drew
(reportedly) a generic "Goto den" call from the NBTHK.

My dilemma, should these wonderful fitting be placed back on the sword or be
kept seperately and "boxed" for individual preservation and appreciation. I
say "dilemma" but in all honesty my choice has been made; they will be boxed
for individual in-hand appreciation. So, should I feel bad to have in a
sense "destroyed" a koshirae or should I feel good to have discovered these
wonderful kodogu. Granted, the koshirae was not truly a (and I hate this
expression) "matching" koshirae and was really "put together" by it pre-war
owner. Yes, I'll keep the saya and (unmounted) tsuka together with a tsunagi
but it seems such a waste to put these beautiful fitting back on it where
they can be damaged (f/k, kozuka/kogai) or hidden under ito (menuki).

After saying all this I'm not too sure where I'm going with it, but my point
might be that there is a time to "preserve" a koshirae" and a time to not
worry about it.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 19, 2004 8:18 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question


I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is
not
touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure
this
is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for
antique
firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.



Jim, care to comment?



Gordon

Entire

> i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
> mumei, they will not be attributed. You must submit the pieces
separately
> for that. If all or some of the pieces are signed, then they will be
> authenticated.

In the case of damaged koshirae, is this a bouncable offense, in which
case once something is damaged it becomes unpaperable?

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon - A personal dilemma. Last March I ve purchased a beautiful mumei katana with fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae which had damage. I ve
messages.messageBody:
Gordon -

A personal dilemma. Last March I've purchased a beautiful mumei katana with fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae which had damage. I've had the sword put into shirazaya and a tsunagi made for the koshirae with repairs, on-going. Because the tsuka wrapping was literally falling apart, the fuchi/kashira and menuki were removed and therefore, able to be examined in-hand. The menuki are solid gold "dragons" which are super! The fuchi/kashira (mumei) are even more fine and really do cry for shinsa with an eye toward Goto. The kozuka/kogai looked "mainline Goto" but drew (reportedly) a generic "Goto den" call from the NBTHK.

My dilemma, should these wonderful fitting be placed back on the sword or be kept seperately and "boxed" for individual preservation and appreciation. I say "dilemma" but in all honesty my choice has been made; they will be boxed for individual in-hand appreciation. So, should I feel bad to have in a sense "destroyed" a koshirae or should I feel good to have discovered these wonderful kodogu. Granted, the koshirae was not truly a (and I hate this expression) "matching" koshirae and was really "put together" by it pre-war owner. Yes, I'll keep the saya and (unmounted) tsuka together with a tsunagi but it seems such a waste to put these beautiful fitting back on it where they can be damaged (f/k, kozuka/kogai) or hidden under ito (menuki).

After saying all this I'm not too sure where I'm going with it, but my point might be that there is a time to "preserve" a koshirae" and a time to not worry about it.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 19, 2004 8:18 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question


I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is not
touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure this
is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for antique
firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.



Jim, care to comment?



Gordon

100
> or so years - that means it is no longer antique and will be bounced.
Entire

> i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
> mumei, they will not be attributed. You must submit the pieces separately
> for that. If all or some of the pieces are signed, then they will be
> authenticated.

In the case of damaged koshirae, is this a bouncable offense, in which
case once something is damaged it becomes unpaperable?

- darcy

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, on the website you write:  These tsuba appear to have been finished by slightly melting the surface after forging and shaping. This brings out
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim, on the website you write: ' These tsuba appear to have been
finished by slightly melting the surface after forging and shaping. This
brings out tekkotsu from the high carbon inclusions in the iron'

Was this done at any other schools or is this peculiar to Kanayama?

Als if you had to translate 'tekkotsu' in English what would it be? I
know what it is (at least I think I do) but I can't for the life of me
think what you would call it in English.

Matt

Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?


Matt,
I think that the metal and the tekkotsu are the first points for
Kanayama. The distinctive motifs would place second (or is that third).
Not all Kanayama guards have wide seppa dai. Earthlink has told me that
my site has already exceeded its bandwidth allotment (it's happening
earlier and earlier in the month), but it hasn't been shut down yet, so
quickly check:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kanayama.htm

Some of them have rather narrow seppa dai.

You're following the right process.
Jim



I think that they went out of fashion is indeed a much more plausible
explanation....... however it is always fun to think about what might
have been. Continuing the subject of Kanayama tsuba, would you say
that
the 'quite large seppa dai in proportion to the rest of the guard'
feature on this type of tsuba is a kantei point? For some reason they
all seem to have a larger seppa dai in relation to the rest of the
design than most other tsuba.

Other kantei points would be the type of steel, the color, the
tekkotsu,
the designs used (often hard to figure out what they represent) etc.

Am I missing any here?

I seem to be getting the knack of distinguishing what is what with all
these different tsuba :- / but that is only because I have spent ages
and ages looking at all kinds of stuff and remembering what such and
such looked like an what school it was. Now I am trying to pinpoint
specific features to help attribute guards more correctly and date
them.
Much like you would do with porcleain with decorative motives and the
paste of the porcelain.

Matt.

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: maandag 19 januari 2004 21:37
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?


Matt,
The short answer is that I don't know.

But, I tend to doubt it. The Norisuke working in the 19th C produced
tekkotsu at will and in their copies sometimes exaggerated them beyond
what was in the originals. Good Kanayama work is still more
attractive,
but how much of that is because of raw material vs. technique vs.
intent?

It's quite possible that Kanayama guards simply went out of style.
The
aesthetic trend in the Edo period moved away from the tastes of the
Muromachi and Momoyama in paintings, ceramics, etc., as well as sword
fittings.
Jim



Gang, how much truth is there to the theory that the Kanayama tsuba
makers used a 'special secret iron ore known only the them and
probably
close to where they worked' that produced the wonderful tekkotsu
effects
in their tsuba? And that when the when they ran out of this
particular
iron ore the school ceased to exist?

Matt

So if I were to take the case of my damaged saya... I don't think that

If I wanted to submit it to shinsa, does the damage mean it won't get a
paper? Or do you accept damaged pieces?

unusual in that the saya is red.

I am pondering this now and since the damage is only to the saya, it

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there. They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming off, it is
messages.messageBody:
I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is not
touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure this
is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for antique
firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.



Jim, care to comment?



Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, I think that the metal and the tekkotsu are the first points for Kanayama.  The distinctive motifs would place second (or is that third).  Not all
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
I think that the metal and the tekkotsu are the first points for Kanayama. The distinctive motifs would place second (or is that third). Not all Kanayama guards have wide seppa dai. Earthlink has told me that my site has already exceeded its bandwidth allotment (it's happening earlier and earlier in the month), but it hasn't been shut down yet, so quickly check:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kanayama.htm

Some of them have rather narrow seppa dai.

You're following the right process.
Jim



I think that they went out of fashion is indeed a much more plausible
explanation....... however it is always fun to think about what might
have been. Continuing the subject of Kanayama tsuba, would you say that
the 'quite large seppa dai in proportion to the rest of the guard'
feature on this type of tsuba is a kantei point? For some reason they
all seem to have a larger seppa dai in relation to the rest of the
design than most other tsuba.

Other kantei points would be the type of steel, the color, the tekkotsu,
the designs used (often hard to figure out what they represent) etc.

Am I missing any here?

I seem to be getting the knack of distinguishing what is what with all
these different tsuba :- / but that is only because I have spent ages
and ages looking at all kinds of stuff and remembering what such and
such looked like an what school it was. Now I am trying to pinpoint
specific features to help attribute guards more correctly and date them.
Much like you would do with porcleain with decorative motives and the
paste of the porcelain.

Matt.

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: maandag 19 januari 2004 21:37
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?


Matt,
The short answer is that I don't know.

But, I tend to doubt it. The Norisuke working in the 19th C produced
tekkotsu at will and in their copies sometimes exaggerated them beyond
what was in the originals. Good Kanayama work is still more attractive,
but how much of that is because of raw material vs. technique vs.
intent?

It's quite possible that Kanayama guards simply went out of style. The
aesthetic trend in the Edo period moved away from the tastes of the
Muromachi and Momoyama in paintings, ceramics, etc., as well as sword
fittings.
Jim



Gang, how much truth is there to the theory that the Kanayama tsuba
makers used a 'special secret iron ore known only the them and
probably
close to where they worked' that produced the wonderful tekkotsu
effects
in their tsuba? And that when the when they ran out of this particular
iron ore the school ceased to exist?

Matt

messages.msgSnippet: Ron, There is a spot on the NTHK koshirae worksheet for an attribution of the complete unit to a maker, but I ve not seen it used for anything mumei.  I m not
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
There is a spot on the NTHK koshirae worksheet for an attribution of the complete unit to a maker, but I've not seen it used for anything mumei. I'm not sure that it's meaningful to talk about a Jingo koshirae, or for that matter a Goto koshirae, even if all of the fittings are by one of those makers.

If the fuchigashira were submitted for kodogu shinsa (while mounted) I don't think that there would be any problem getting a Jingo attribution if that's what they are. I don't think I've seen the tsuka, but it sounds nice. If it turned out to be later generation Jingo, it would get a "kodai" qualifier, as with the Yagyu tsuba that Cary mentioned yesterday.

Jim



Hi Jim -

As an example, I have a tsuka with nice doe skin wrap and what I believe to be Jingo iron fuchi/kashira and menuki. If this opinion is correct (Jingo), having the fittings "in hand" would show them to be mumei anyway. Do you think a shinsa team would make the call to Jingo in a case like this? I've often wondered about submitting this tsuka but that's yet to be done. (Perhaps you saw this tsuba somewhere over the years.)

Ron
STL

-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Tuesday, January 20, 2004 6:35 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question



Cary,
Good to hear your voice on the list again.

Based on my limited experience with overseas NTHK shinsa, the criteria are
similar. One difference is that submissions for koshirae shinsa, including
tsuka-only submissions, will have the signatures of the kodogu elements
noted where visible, but will not get attributions of maker or time period
for any unsigned kodogu elements.

So, Milt's tsuka, if genuine, would be described in detail as to materials,
carving and inlay techniques, decorative motifs, and be measured and
photographed, but would not receive maker attributions for the menuki or
fuchigashira. A date and point value for the koshirae as a unit will be
provided, but not for the individual kodogu elements.

Agreed that a tsuba and tsuka without a saya is not an appropriate
submission for koshirae shinsa.

A customer can submit a complete koshirae for shinsa and then, for example,
submit the mumei tsuba separately as kodogu if an attribution of maker, time
period and point value is desired. This requires two submissions, though.

An advantage of overseas shinsa is that we can immediately contact the owner
of the item if there is a problem with the submission. For example, if a
tsuka is submitted for koshirae shinsa and the fuchigashira are genuine but
the menuki are reproductions, we will track down the owner and advise him
that the item will fail as koshirae due to the menuki, but that if he would
like to change the submission (no additional charge) to kodogu shinsa of the
fuchigashira, it can be certified. We "saved" a nice Omori Teruhide F/K
this way.

Jim





Milt,
I cannot speak for the NTHK.
Jim will be able to answer the shinsa criteria for fittings.

My experience with the NBTHK is:
You can submit the entire tsuka.
If any element is false (gimei FK, cast menuki)it will not pass.
If all is proper it will paper as "Tsuka mae".
The mei of the FK will be noted.
If there is no mei it will likely be attributed.

The tsuba will require a separate submission.

Twofer's include Daisho Tsuba, Daisho FKs, or Menuki,
Futokoro or Mitokoromono, and of course Daisho koshirae.

Cary Condell

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Cary and Milt, This is good timing as I wanted to warn Chicago shinsa attendees about submitting koshirae. If you submit a tsuka, then the same will apply
messages.messageBody:
Hi Cary and Milt,



This is good timing as I wanted to warn Chicago shinsa attendees about
submitting koshirae. If you submit a tsuka, then the same will apply as with
the NBTHK. Make sure that the tsuka has not been re-wrapped in the last 100
or so years - that means it is no longer antique and will be bounced. Entire
koshirae will be judged based on authenticity and age of all the pieces,
i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
mumei, they will not be attributed. You must submit the pieces separately
for that. If all or some of the pieces are signed, then they will be
authenticated.



Gordon

It's quite possible that Kanayama guards simply went out of style. The aesthetic trend in the Edo period moved away from the tastes of the Muromachi and Momoyama in paintings, ceramics, etc., as well as sword fittings.

Gang, how much truth is there to the theory that the Kanayama tsuba
makers used a 'special secret iron ore known only the them and probably
close to where they worked' that produced the wonderful tekkotsu effects
in their tsuba? And that when the when they ran out of this particular
iron ore the school ceased to exist?

Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, I cannot speak for the NTHK. Jim will be able to answer the shinsa criteria for fittings. My experience with the NBTHK is: You can submit the entire
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
I cannot speak for the NTHK.
Jim will be able to answer the shinsa criteria for fittings.

My experience with the NBTHK is:
You can submit the entire tsuka.
If any element is false (gimei FK, cast menuki)it will not pass.
If all is proper it will paper as "Tsuka mae".
The mei of the FK will be noted.
If there is no mei it will likely be attributed.

The tsuba will require a separate submission.

Twofer's include Daisho Tsuba, Daisho FKs, or Menuki,
Futokoro or Mitokoromono, and of course Daisho koshirae.

Cary Condell
